Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): handle deep imports that already have an extension
Issues.Body:
**refactor(ngcc): avoid repeated file resolution during dependency scan**

During the recursive processing of dependencies, ngcc resolves the
requested file to an actual location on disk, by testing various
extensions. For recursive calls however, the path is known to have been
resolved in the module resolver. Therefore, it is safe to move the path
resolution to the initial caller into the recursive process.

Note that this is not expected to improve the performance of ngcc, as
the call to `resolveFileWithPostfixes` is known to succeed immediately,
as the provided path is known to exist without needing to add any
postfixes. Furthermore, the FileSystem caches whether files exist, so
the additional check that we used to do was cheap.

---

**fix(ngcc): handle deep imports that already have an extension**

During the dependency analysis phase of ngcc, imports are resolved to
files on disk according to certain module resolution rules. Since module
specifiers are typically missing extensions, or can refer to index.js
barrel files within a directory, the module resolver attempts several
postfixes when searching for a module import on disk. Module  specifiers
that already include an extension, however, would fail to be resolved as
ngcc's module resolver failed to check the location on disk without
adding any postfixes.

Closes #32097
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ngcc): handle deep imports that already have an extension" (#32181)

Issues.Title: change detection wrong order on child components
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Life cycle and Change detection not running in the correct order for 2 sibling components. ### Is this a regression? Not that I'm aware of. ### Description I have 2 sibling components. The first hosts a template via ngTemplateOutlet The 2nd has the template as part of its view to be used by it's sibling. The parent gets the template from the 2nd child and passes it to the first child. It works fine if the template that we're getting from the 2nd child gets passed to the 1st child in the first cycle. However, if we need a 2nd cycle to get the template like the following code it doesn't work. 

  ngAfterViewInit() {
    setTimeout(() => {
      this.templates = this.templateQuery.map( c => c.template );
      this.cdr.markForCheck();
    }, 0);
  }
Doing it in the set timeout is necessary otherwise you may get a ExpressionChangedAfterItHasBeenCheckedError. The input bindings on the inner template are always one cycle behind the parent component. The issue appears to be that the order that angular runs the life cycle hooks is not the same in the 1st case as in the 2nd. In the first case. The content is checked on the template component before the host component. So the change is detected and passed through to the host component. However in the 2nd case Change detection first runs on the host component and nothing changed yet so the view doesn't update. Then it's run on the template component, but it's already too late for the host component. So it's not picked up till the next cycle. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction click the button and notice the inner template in the broken section is one step behind. https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-djxc1a ## üî• Exception or Error The view isn't updated correctly. The child is one cycle behind the parent. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 



Angular CLI: 8.2.2
Node: 12.6.0
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 8.2.2
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.802.2
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.802.2
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.802.2
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.802.2
@angular-devkit/core              8.2.2
@angular-devkit/schematics        8.2.2
@angular/cdk                      8.1.3
@angular/material                 8.1.3
@ngtools/webpack                  8.2.2
@schematics/angular               8.2.2
@schematics/update                0.802.2
rxjs                              6.4.0
typescript                        3.5.3
webpack                           4.38.0
**Anything else relevant?** It's possible this is by design. If that's the case it should be documented how the life cycle behaves for these edge cases.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "change detection wrong order on child components" (#32180)

Issues.Title: Incorrect path to Angular library
Issues.Body:
I am using Angular library and have the following folder structure:
```
coollibrary
  - components
    - my.component.ts
  - services
    - my.service.ts
public_api.ts
```
In public_api, I export the component and service and make the library build.
After that I can import the necessary things in my project using
```
import { MyComponent } from 'coollibrary';
```
but I can not use the following path:
```
import { MyComponent  } from 'coollibrary/components'
```
Can I use correct path?

Issues.Title: Support type-then-feature naming convention
Issues.Body:
Related: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/15351

support type-first naming which is more intuitive and efficient for some users and systems, plus it is consistent with hungarian-like naming which is an additional type guard in situations where TS isn't typesafe.

Currently, requiring hungarian-like naming and angular naming guidelines compliance leads to some rediculous situations like:
`import { ServiceAnalyticsService } from './service-analytics/service-analytics.service.ts`

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): use the schema registry to check DOM bindings
Issues.Body:
Previously, ngtsc attempted to use the .d.ts schema for HTML elements to
check bindings to DOM properties. However, the TypeScript lib.dom.d.ts
schema does not perfectly align with the Angular DomElementSchemaRegistry,
and these inconsistencies would cause issues in apps. There is also the
concern of supporting both CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA and NO_ERRORS_SCHEMA which
would have been very difficult to do in the existing system.

With this commit, the DomElementSchemaRegistry is employed in ngtsc to check
bindings to the DOM. Previous work on producing template diagnostics is used
to support generation of this different kind of error with the same high
quality of error message.

---

Reviewers: only the last commit is important.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(ivy): use the schema registry to check DOM bindings" (#32171)

Issues.Title: refactor(language-service): Omit typechecking for finding directives
Issues.Body:
Remove unnecessary private method `getDeclarationFromNode` and moved
some logic to utils instead so that it can be tested in isolation of the
Language Service infrastructure.
The use of typechecker to check the directive is also not necessary,
since `resolver.getNonNormalizedDirectiveMetadata()` will check if the
directive is actually an Angular entity.

Misc:
- Fixed typo for `getTightestNode()`
- Added extra test for `getClassDeclFromTemplateNode()`

Issues.Title: perf(ivy): avoid for-of loops at runtime
Issues.Body:
TypeScript downlevels `for-of` loops for ES5 targets. As a result, generated output contains extra code, including a try-catch block, which has code size and performance implications. This is especially important for runtime code where we want to keep it as small as possible. This commit changes `for-of` loops in runtime code to regular `for` loops.

Issues.Title: Tslib as peerDependency
Issues.Body:
**feat(bazel): do not embed tslib in UMD bundles when using ng_package rule**

**BREAKING CHANGE**: with this change we no longer embed `tslib` in the UMD bundles when using `ng_package` rule users using this rule to bundle their library are required to change tslib from `dependency` to `peerDepedency`.

From:
```
"dependencies": {
  "tslib": "^1.9.0"
}
```
To:
```
"peerDependencies": {
  "tslib": "^1.9.0"
},
```

Reference: TOOL-836


refactor: change tslib from dependency to peerDependency 

**BREAKING CHANGE**: `tslib` now a peerDependency of the Angular packages. Consumers need to add a direct dependency to tslib if they don't have it already.

```
yarn add tslib
npm install tslib --save
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Tslib as peerDependency" (#32167)

Issues.Title: [SECURITY] URL Redirection to Untrusted Site ('Open Redirect') CWE ID 601
Issues.Body:
I have already emailed this to `security@angular.io` but no response since a long time.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Description
An http parameter may contain a URL value and could cause the web application to redirect the request to the specified URL. By modifying the URL value to a malicious site, an attacker may successfully launch a phishing scam and steal user credentials. Because the server name in the modified link is identical to the original site, phishing attempts have a more trustworthy appearance.

Remediation
The easiest and most effective way to prevent vulnerable open redirects would be to not let the user control where your page redirects him to. If you have to redirect the user based on URLs, you should always use an ID which is internally resolved to the respective URL.

To the extent possible, use relative URLs as absolute URLs are more vulnerable. 
With relative URLs, it can be ensured that the request cannot go to external sites, which is not the case with absolute URLs. 
The following instances of the vulnerability have been reported in platform code, and need to be mitigated.

Developer(s) looking into mitigating the reported vulnerability have the following options. 
a) Modify the code to mitigate the vulnerability if it is ascertained that a vulnerability exists.
b) Modify the code to add defensive code if there is a possibility of vulnerability. 
c) Provide feedback to say that there is no vulnerability with the following options.

Potential False Positive
Mitigated by Design
Mitigated by OS environment
Mitigated by Network environment

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ngTemplateOutlet error when switching between null and template value
Issues.Body:
Fixes an error that is thrown by `ngTemplateOutlet` under Ivy when switching from a template to null and back to a template. The error is thrown because the reference to the previous ViewRef is never cleared and the directive tries to detach a view that has already been detached.

Fixes #32060.

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
angular CLI


### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
currently when a component is generated it might be called x.component.ts and a service like y.service.ts

This has a few negative effects in my book:
1 - sorting by name does not group components and services together.
2 - Hungarian-like naming becomes awkward, eg `ServiceAnalyticsService`. Service is prepended in the hungarian-like system I like, but it also has to be appended to comply with angular convention.
3 - it doesn't seem possible to programmatically or humanly know whether a folder under app refers to a component, service, module...by looking at the folder name when generating a non-flat entity.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
1 - An option to have the files generated with flipped naming like component.x.ts and service.y.ts
2 - A different option to allow type to be added to the folder name without redundancy. So normal mode is `x-component/x.component.ts` and flipped is `component-x/component.x.ts`


### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
I'm personally OK with the redundant naming but my team isn't. So a key workaround would be having a component called ComponentThingComponent or ServiceSomeService.

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): expose webpack-dev-server's allowedHosts option
Issues.Body:
This PR adds `allowedHosts` as option and passes it along to the dev server. Issue #13656 describes a use-case for this. My use-case is slightly different, as I'm working on a multi-tenant application that derives the tenant from the host name. Having access to `allowedHosts` makes it possible to define multiple hosts pointing to 127.0.0.1 and using them to access the dev server (during development).

A test was added, but I'm not entirely happy with the end result. The `beforeEach` and `afterEach` are duplicate with `public-host_spec_large.ts` (although more spec files have the exact same code). It might also be better to combine it with the public-host spec file, as some test cases in there (no options specified, or with `disableHostCheck`) also apply to the `allowedHosts` option.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): expose webpack-dev-server's allowedHosts option" (#15366)

Issues.Title: ng upgrade V7->V8: missing peer dependency error for project including @ngtools/webpack
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [x] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? n/a Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... When attempting to upgrade a project from V7 to V8, if the project includes '@ngtools/webpack' but not the peer dependency 'webpack' the upgrade fails. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. Create a new project Angular V7 project using 'ngNew' 2. Add '@ngtools/webpack' using 'npm install @ngtools/webpack' 3. Attempt to update the project using 'ng update @angular/cli @angular/core'. You will get an error: Package "@ngtools/webpack" has an incompatible peer dependency to "typescript" (requires ">=2.4.0 < 3.3", would install "3.5.3"). 4. So add @ngtools/webpack to the command line (i.e.) ng update @angular/cli @angular/core @ngtools/webpack 5. You will get the error: Package "@ngtools/webpack" has a missing peer dependency of "webpack" @ "^4.0.0". Adding webpack using 'npm install webpack' before upgrading causes the upgrade to be successful. Removing 'webpack' using 'npm uninstall webpack' after the upgrade removes it from the project.json and node_modules and causes ng serve to show the following error: An unhandled exception occurred: Cannot find module 'webpack' Note also that 'webpack' appears to be in the node_modules by default even if not listed explicitly in the package.json (unless removed as described above in which case npm install does not seem to restore it). ## üî• Exception or Error 



Package "@ngtools/webpack" has a missing peer dependency of "webpack" @ "^4.0.0".

Issues.Title: Incorrect path to Angular library
Issues.Body:
I am using Angular library and have the following folder structure:
```
coollibrary
  - components
    - my.component.ts
  - services
    - my.service.ts
public_api.ts
```
In public_api, I export the component and service and make the library build.
After that I can import the necessary things in my project using
```
import { MyComponent } from 'coollibrary';
```
but I can not use the following path:
```
import { MyComponent  } from 'coollibrary/components'
```
Can I use correct path?

Issues.Title: Add ability to compile/generate asset files
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
My angular project has multiple environment files and various build configurations. There in, I use the replace feature to replace different manifest and index files depending on the configuration I choose when I build/serve the project.

I would like to add a version field to the manifest and index meta tags. But I don't like having to change all 8 files every time I update the version number.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.

Ideally I would like the ability to tell CLI to insert a version number which would be set in one location into each specified file, somehow, so I don't have to do it manually.

Along with the different configurations and file replacement properties in the angular.json file... perhaps add the ability to do string find/replace on specified files from a given source.

Or better yet add some other versioning functionality into it so that it also increments the version number on every build.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
The only alternative I have seen would be to use php or some other back end scripting language to compile the html and manifest files. But since this is fairly basic variable insertions adding in the overhead of a backend script compiler seemed a bit overkill. Especially since the variable insertion does not need to be dynamic after the build/serve command is run.

Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ 

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
angular CLI


### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
currently when a component is generated it might be called x.component.ts and a service like y.service.ts

This has a few negative effects in my book:
1 - sorting by name does not group components and services together.
2 - Hungarian-like naming becomes awkward, eg `ServiceAnalyticsService`. Service is prepended in the hungarian-like system I like, but it also has to be appended to comply with angular convention.
3 - it doesn't seem possible to programmatically or humanly know whether a folder under app refers to a component, service, module...by looking at the folder name when generating a non-flat entity.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
1 - An option to have the files generated with flipped naming like component.x.ts and service.y.ts
2 - A different option to allow type to be added to the folder name without redundancy. So normal mode is `x-component/x.component.ts` and flipped is `component-x/component.x.ts`


### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
I'm personally OK with the redundant naming but my team isn't. So a key workaround would be having a component called ComponentThingComponent or ServiceSomeService.


ref: https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/32158

Issues.Title: Build process with AoT converts variable calls to null on source code
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [X ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Description I build a sub module (Logger module) that implements the forRoot static method, and required an object structured like this: export interface LoggerOptions { loggerType: LoggerType; << Enum data: any; environment: any; } on AppModule, I'm importing the sub module and calling the forRoot function and passing the required object, while using the values below: loggerType - hard coded value from the enum data - object (**type: any**) from pre initiated config data environment - string (tried to wrap as object as well, **type: any**) from pre initiated config data **THE ISSUE:** After opening the app again, the sub module always pass to it's services null on the environment field. I couldn't figure out what was the problem - because when I'm building on development mode it's fine. So I looked into the main.js file, and then I saw a weird behavior that I don't think I can expect from the compiler: {data:Re,environment:null,loggerType:"hspLogger"} for some reason, the AoT compiler convert the variable call to null value inside the main.js source code. I first thought that it might be related to the variable is a string and it's not initialized on the build procedure - so it converts it to null value, but I tried to change the environment property to object as well and it's still converts it to null on the source code. **what's the difference between environment and data?** **why data variable is staying as is and doesn't get this behavior as well?** ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. create a simple project (angular cli ^7.2.1, angular compiler-cli 7.2.0) 2. create sub module that implements forRoot static method and requires an object like mine: export interface LoggerOptions { loggerType: LoggerType; << Enum data: any; environment: any; } 3. import the module to AppModule and call the forRoot static method, pass it an object with dynamic variables (not pre-initialized with values) ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: Changes in partial scss files are not respected when using ng serve --aot on Windows
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 8.1 ### Description When partial scss files are used (`scss` files which names start with `_`), `ng serve --aot` on Windows does not detect changes in them. This is not happening when `--aot` is not passed. Also everything works fine on macOS and Linux. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction You can find a sample project reproducing the issue here: https://github.com/rosen-vladimirov/angular-scss-windows-aot-issue The project was created with `ng new --style scss`, without router. After that I've included the partial scss file and used it in `app.component`. Run `ng serve --aot` **on Windows** and apply a change in the partial scss file. Nothing happens. ## üî• Exception or Error No error, just the changes are not detected and they are not applied. ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: docs(ng-add): docs don't mention that the library will be installed in the project of the CWD
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. `ng new tmp` and respond to prompts
1. `cd tmp/`
1. `ng g app web-app` and respond to prompts
1. Edit workspace (`angular.json`) to change `"defaultProject": "tmp"` to `"defaultProject": "web-app"`
 1. `ng add @angular/material` and respond to prompts
 
#### Expected Behavior
[The `ng add` docs](https://angular.io/cli/add) state
> Adds the npm package for a published library to your workspace, and configures your default app project to use that library,

> The default app project is the value of `defaultProject` in `angular.json`.

Thus it is expected to add Angular Material to the default project, `web-app`.

#### Actual Behavior
```bash
Skipping installation: Package already installed
? Choose a prebuilt theme name, or "custom" for a custom theme: Custom
? Set up HammerJS for gesture recognition? Yes
? Set up browser animations for Angular Material? Yes
UPDATE package.json (1473 bytes)
UPDATE src/main.ts (391 bytes)
UPDATE src/app/app.module.ts (423 bytes)
UPDATE src/styles.scss (1418 bytes)
UPDATE src/index.html (484 bytes)
```
As you can see, it configured the initial app project in the workspace (`"tmp"`) for Angular Material instead of the default project (`"web-app"`).

#### Environment
```bash
Angular CLI: 8.2.1
Node: 10.15.3
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 8.2.1
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                            Version
------------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect          0.802.1
@angular-devkit/build-angular      0.802.1
@angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr   0.802.1
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer    0.802.1
@angular-devkit/build-webpack      0.802.1
@angular-devkit/core               8.2.1
@angular-devkit/schematics         8.2.1
@angular/cdk                       8.1.2
@angular/material                  8.1.2
@ngtools/webpack                   8.2.1
@schematics/angular                8.2.1
@schematics/update                 0.802.1
ng-packagr                         5.4.3
rxjs                               6.4.0
typescript                         3.5.3
webpack                            4.38.0
```

Ran into this while reviewing PR https://github.com/angular/components/pull/16654.

Issues.Title: fix(material-experimental/chips): high contrast mode fixes
Issues.Body:
Fixes the following issues with the MDC-based chips in high contrast mode:
* Chips blending in with the background because they don't have an outline or a border.
* No focus indication being visible.
* Chips being hidden completely on hover because we were using an RGBA overlay.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(material-experimental/chips): high contrast mode fixes" (#16811)

Issues.Title: fix(tabs): tabs with background overriding ripple color for all descendants
Issues.Body: When a tab group has a background color we need to change its ripple color so it doesn't blend in with the background, however the current selector is too broad which means that it also targets all the ripples inside the tabs content. These changes narrow down the selector to avoid the issue.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(tabs): tabs with background overriding ripple color for all descendants" (#16810)

Issues.Title: fix(stepper): remove tabindex from content
Issues.Body:
A while ago in #14892 we added a `tabindex` to the content of the current step based on a recommendation from W3C a11y guidelines, however since then we consulted with the a11y team and it looks like adding the `tabindex` there isn't the best approach.

Fixes #16692.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(stepper): remove tabindex from content" (#16809)

Issues.Title: fix(expansion): not adding margin for all button types
Issues.Body: Currently the margins for buttons inside the `mat-action-row` is only set up for `mat-button`, however we have other variants like raised and stroked buttons which haven't been accounted for.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(expansion): not adding margin for all button types" (#16806)

Issues.Title: prototype(tabs): create prototype tabs based on MDC web
Issues.Body:
Adds an implementation of the Angular Material tabs that is based on MDC web. The API is exactly the same, except for a couple of differences:

1. The ink bar has been switched to use MDC's `tab-indicator`. As such the styling and the animation are slightly different.
2. Previously `MatTabLink` used to be a `Directive`, however now it's a `Component`, because we need some extra markup around the content.

**Note:** this is **not** merge safe, because I had to move a few things around in the current tabs module.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "prototype(tabs): create prototype tabs based on MDC web" (#16805)

Issues.Title: prototype(slider): create prototype slider based on MDC web
Issues.Body:
Creates a prototype of `mat-slider` that uses MDC web. The feature comparison document has been filled.

A list of notable bugs in the MDC foundation right now:

* input event not rounded before comparing (causing multiple `input` events; workaround applied)
* Thumb label not updating if value changes programmatically (workaround applied)
* Slider updates value with right mouse events
* change event always fired on mouse up or keydown
* slider measurements and ticks only updated on init and "resize" event
  * standard Angular Material slider did this on `mouseenter`.
* Vertical alignment (incorrect calculations; currently shifted down 2px of baseline)

Notable feature differences:

* Visually sliders look totally different to our current implementation
* Vertical sliders are not supported (yet?)
* Sliders do not support decimal steps.
* Sliders cannot be inverted (no support in the foundation)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "prototype(slider): create prototype slider based on MDC web" (#16795)

Issues.Title: fix(schematics): module imports not generated for schematics
Issues.Body:
Currently in some scenarios the CLI project has a different TypeScript version
than the `typescript` version used in the `@schematics/angular` package.

This causes AST parsing & transformations to be broken due to the shifted
values (e.g. in the `SyntaxKind` enum). Previously we solved this by always
using the `typescript` version brought in by the `@schematics/angular` package,
but this no longer works as of v8.0.0 CLI because the `@schematics/angular`
package now vendors `typescript` instead of having an explicit version as
dependency.

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/commit/bf1c069f73c8e3d4f0e8d584cbfb47c408c1730b
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(schematics): module imports not generated for schematics" (#16787)

Issues.Title: fix(schematics): navigation schematic not respecting breakpoints on initial render
Issues.Body:
https://github.com/angular/material2/commit/a6cdcfc5cbc08450ece2bfed375b310780fb213c added the `share()` operator to the `isHandset$` observable. This accidentally
broke the initial rendering of the navigation as the view subscribes to the observable
(through `async` pipe) after the initial value has been emitted. Meaning that `isHandset$ | async`
expression always evaluates to `null` until the breakpoint changes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(schematics): navigation schematic not respecting breakpoints on initial render" (#16788)
